newsitem.title: USA: Football coach claims NIKE rips off PLAY.
newsitem.headline: Football coach claims NIKE rips off PLAY.

text.p: A Massachusetts basketball coach has claimed in court papers that Nike Inc.'s PLAY marketing campaign unfairly copied a minority youth programme he has run under the same acronym since 1990.

In the federal lawsuit filed in Springfield, Mass., Dennis Jackson alleges Nike based its Participate in the Lives of America's Youth programme, or PLAY, on a non-profit summer institute for minority youth he has operated in Massachusetts since 1990.
The Oregon-based atheletic footwear maker had no comment on the suit Monday.
Jackson is seeking damages in excess of $1 million, according to the court paper.
"I'm just really disappointed in Nike's posture in the way they treated the whole situation," Jackson said.

Between 1991 and 1993, Jackson sought financial backing from Nike for his programme, which he called Planned Learned Achievement for Youth, or PLAY. It is a basketball camp that stresses personal growth and includes academic counselling, the court papers said.
Jackson alleged he relayed proposals to the company through superstar Michael Jordan, who attended a basketball camp run by Jackson in the 1970s.
Nike rejected Jackson's appeals for backing several times and then it created its own programme in 1994, the court papers said.
Jackson complained to Nike after learning it had created its own programme, the suit says, and the company promised to support the Massachusetts programme in 1995.
The suit says Nike offered Jackson both financial support and marketing help, but did not follow through on the agreement.
Jackson is dean of students at a junior high school in Amherst, Mass. He runs his summer programme on the campus of Mount Holyoke College in South Hadley, Mass.
Nike's stock rose 87.5 cents to $53 on the New York Stock Exchange in early afternoon trading.
